original: Herbert Simon's characterization of information overload as an economic issue has gained prominence in the analysis of information consumption since the mid-1990s. Influential writers such as Thomas H. Davenport and Michael Goldhaber introduced concepts like "attention economy" and "economics of attention" to describe this phenomenon. Some theorists propose that "attention transactions" may supplant financial transactions as the central
